If, at the end of the trial of an election petition, it appears to the Court that a specified person may have engaged in corrupt or illegal conduct at or in connection with the election, the Court is required to provide the Director of Public Prosecutions with a report giving details of the conduct.

section.name: s45A
section.heading: Court’s determination of election petition suspended before deadline of appeal
section.content: The effect of the determination of the Court of an election petition is suspended until the expiry of the period within which notice of a motion for the purpose of an application for leave to appeal to the Court of Final Appeal against the determination may be filed under section 43(2).

section.name: s45B
section.heading: Court of Final Appeal’s determination
section.leadIn: At the end of the hearing of an appeal against the determination of the Court of an election petition, the Court of Final Appeal must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: determine—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: if the election petition relates to an election that was not contested—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: whether the decision of the Returning Officer as to the validity of the relevant nomination was correct; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: if the decision was not correct, whether the person declared to have been elected in that election was or was not duly elected;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: if the election petition relates to an election that was contested—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: whether the person whose election is questioned was or was not duly elected; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: if the person was not duly elected, whether some other person was duly elected in place of the person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: announce its determination by means of a written judgment.

section.name: s46
section.heading: What happens if election petition is withdrawn

subsection.content: Subject to section 44(3), a petitioner shall not withdraw or abandon, or cease to prosecute, an election petition unless the petitioner has obtained the leave of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: At the hearing of an application for leave mentioned in subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any person who could have lodged an election petition in respect of the election concerned, or the Secretary for Justice, may apply to the Court to be substituted as a petitioner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court may, if it thinks appropriate, accordingly substitute that person or the Secretary for Justice for the original petitioner.

subsection.content: If an application to withdraw or abandon, or to cease to prosecute, an election petition is, in the opinion of the Court, induced by a corrupt bargain or the offer or giving of corrupt consideration, the Court may direct that the security given by or on behalf of the original petitioner is to remain as security for any costs that are incurred by the substituted petitioner. To the extent of such sum as the Court directs, the original petitioner (and that original petitioner’s sureties, if any) is to be liable to pay the costs of the substituted petitioner.

If the Court does not so direct, then before the substituted petitioner may proceed with the substituted election petition, security of the same amount as would be required to be given under section 44 in the case of an original election petition shall be given by or on behalf of that petitioner in the same manner and form, and within such period, as the Court directs. This subsection does not apply to the Secretary for Justice.
Subject to subsections (3) and (4), a substituted petitioner stands in the same position as the original petitioner.

If a petitioner is substituted for the original petitioner, the original petitioner shall provide the substituted petitioner with all evidence available to the original petitioner and relevant to the continued prosecution of the election petition.

subsection.leadIn: The petitioner is liable to pay the costs of the respondent if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the election petition is withdrawn or abandoned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the petition is taken to have been withdrawn under section 44(3); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the petitioner ceases to prosecute the petition.

subsection.content: If there are 2 or more petitioners, an application to withdraw or abandon, or to cease to prosecute, the election petition can be made only with the consent of all the petitioners.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contravenes subsection (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with subsection (6),

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s47
section.heading: When an election petition is terminated

subsection.content: If an election petition is lodged by one petitioner, the petition is terminated by that petitioner’s death.
If an election petition is lodged by 2 or more petitioners, the petition is terminated if the last remaining petitioner dies.

The termination of an election petition under this section does not affect the liability of the estate of the deceased petitioner, or the liability of any other person, for the payment of costs previously incurred.
On the termination of an election petition under this section, the Registrar of the High Court shall publish in the Gazette a notice of the termination.

Within 14 days after the publication of such a notice, any person who could have lodged an election petition in respect of the election concerned may apply to the Court in writing to be substituted as a petitioner. On receiving such an application, the Court may, if it thinks appropriate, substitute the applicant for the original petitioner.
The same security shall be given by or on behalf of the substituted petitioner as would be required to be given by or on behalf of the original petitioner.

section.name: s48
section.heading: When respondent can withdraw from election petition proceedings and be substituted

subsection.leadIn: If, before the trial of an election petition, a respondent other than a Returning Officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: dies, resigns or otherwise ceases to hold the office of rural representative to which the petition relates; or (Amended 5 of 2014 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: gives the Registrar of the High Court notice that the respondent does not intend to oppose the petition,

subsection.continued: that the Registrar shall publish in the Gazette a notice of that fact.

subsection.content: Within 14 days after the publication of such a notice, any person who could have lodged an election petition in respect of the election concerned may apply to the Court in writing to be substituted as a respondent to oppose the petition. On receiving such an application, the Court shall order the applicant to be substituted as a respondent to the petition.
A respondent who has given notice under subsection (1)(b) cannot appear or participate in the proceedings on the election petition in opposition to the petition.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Acts of person not invalid if determined not duly elected
section.content: If the Court or the Court of Final Appeal determines that a person who was originally declared to have been duly elected as a Rural Representative for a Rural Area at an election was not duly elected as the Rural Representative for the Rural Area, the determination does not invalidate acts purporting to have been done by the person as the Rural Representative for the Rural Area before the date on which the written judgment of the Court or the Court of Final Appeal, as the case may be, is handed down.

section.name: s50
section.heading: What is to happen if a Rural Representative is determined not duly elected

subsection.leadIn: If, on the hearing of an election petition, the Court determines that a person who was declared under section 36 as duly elected as a Rural Representative was not duly elected as a Rural Representative— (Amended 18 of 2011 s. 30; 5 of 2014 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (1A) and section 45A, that person ceases to be a Rural Representative; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (2), that person’s office as a Rural Representative becomes vacant from the date on which the written judgment of the Court is handed down.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Court determines that a person who was declared under section 36 as duly elected as a Rural Representative was not duly elected as a Rural Representative; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person lodges an appeal under section 22(1)(c) of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 484) against the determination,

subsection.continued: the person continues, subject to subsections (3) and (5), to be a Rural Representative. (Added 18 of 2011 s. 30)

subsection.content: If, on the hearing of an election petition, the Court determines that a person was duly elected as a Rural Representative for a Rural Area in place of a person that the Court has determined not to have been duly elected for the Rural Area at the election, subject to subsection (1A) and section 45A, the first-mentioned person becomes a Rural Representative for the Rural Area from the date on which the written judgment of the Court is handed down.

subsection.leadIn: If, on the hearing of an appeal against the determination of the Court of an election petition, the Court of Final Appeal determines that a person who was declared under section 36 as duly elected as a Rural Representative was not duly elected as a Rural Representative— (Amended 5 of 2014 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that person ceases to be a Rural Representative; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (4), that person’s office as a Rural Representative becomes vacant from the date on which the written judgment of the Court of Final Appeal is handed down. (Added 18 of 2011 s. 30)

subsection.content: If, on the hearing of an appeal against the determination of the Court of an election petition, the Court of Final Appeal determines that a person was duly elected as a Rural Representative in place of a person that the Court of Final Appeal has determined not to have been duly elected as a Rural Representative, the first-mentioned person becomes a Rural Representative from the date on which the written judgment of the Court of Final Appeal is handed down. (Added 18 of 2011 s. 30)

subsection.leadIn: If the Court determines that a person who was declared under section 36 as duly elected as a Rural Representative was not duly elected as a Rural Representative and the person lodges an appeal under section 22(1)(c) of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 484) against the determination, the person— (Amended 5 of 2014 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ceases, if an application to withdraw an application for leave to appeal or an application to withdraw an appeal is made under rule 11 or 17 (as the case may be) of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Rules (Cap. 484 sub. leg. A) in relation to the appeal and an order is made by the Court of Final Appeal granting the application, to be a Rural Representative on the date on which the order is made by the Court of Final Appeal; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ceases, if the appeal proceedings are terminated in other circumstances, to be a Rural Representative on the date on which the appeal proceedings are terminated,

subsection.continued: and the determination of the Court against which the appeal is lodged stands from that date. (Added 18 of 2011 s. 30)

section.name: s51
section.heading: Appointment of Electoral Registration Officer and assistants

subsection.content: The Secretary shall appoint an Electoral Registration Officer and such number of Assistant Electoral Registration Officers as appears to the Secretary to be necessary for the purposes of registering persons as electors at elections.
The Electoral Registration Officer has such functions as are imposed or conferred on the Officer by or under this Ordinance or the EAC Regulations.
An Assistant Electoral Registration Officer may, with the authority of the Electoral Registration Officer, perform the functions of Electoral Registration Officer.
The Secretary shall publish in the Gazette a notice of the appointment of a person as the Electoral Registration Officer and the Officer’s address.

The Government shall ensure that the Electoral Registration Officer is provided with such staff as the Officer requires in order to perform the Officer’s functions under this Ordinance or the EAC Regulations.

Expenses properly incurred by the Electoral Registration Officer in the performance of the Officer’s functions under this Ordinance or the EAC Regulations are a charge on, and are payable from, the general revenue.

section.name: s52
section.heading: Electoral Registration Officer may specify forms
section.content: The Electoral Registration Officer may specify the form of any application, notice, return, record or other document required for the purposes of this Ordinance.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Appointment of Revising Officer

subsection.content: The Chief Justice may appoint an eligible person to be a Revising Officer for the purposes of this Ordinance. (Amended 1 of 2019 s. 73)
If no appointment is made under subsection (1), the Registrar of the High Court is taken to be a Revising Officer.
A Revising Officer has such functions as are imposed or conferred on the Officer by or under this Ordinance.
A Revising Officer has, when performing the Officer’s functions, the powers and immunities of a magistrate under sections 21, 22, 99, 125 and 126 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227).

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)—

def.name: EligiblePerson
def.leadIn: eligible person (合資格人士) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a magistrate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a former magistrate; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a retired magistrate. (Added 1 of 2019 s. 73)

section.name: s54
section.heading: Appointment of Returning Officers and assistants

subsection.content: The Electoral Affairs Commission shall appoint for each Rural Area a Returning Officer and such number of Assistant Returning Officers as appears to the Secretary to be necessary to enable an election to be held for the Rural Area. (Amended 5 of 2014 s. 2)
A Returning Officer has such functions as are imposed or conferred on the Officer by or under this Ordinance or the EAC Regulations.
An Assistant Returning Officer may, with the authority of the Returning Officer concerned, perform the functions of Returning Officer.
The Secretary shall publish in the Gazette a notice of the appointment of a person as a Returning Officer and the Officer’s address.
The Government shall ensure that each Returning Officer is provided with such staff as the Officer requires in order to perform the Officer’s functions under this Ordinance or the EAC Regulations.
Expenses properly incurred by a Returning Officer in the performance of the Officer’s functions under this Ordinance or the EAC Regulations are a charge on, and are payable from, the general revenue.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Offence to obstruct or hinder electoral officer
section.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, obstructs or hinders, or interferes with, an electoral officer in the performance of a function imposed, or conferred, by or under this Ordinance or the Electoral Affairs Commission Ordinance (Cap. 541) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 2.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Secretary may give directions as to performance of electoral officer’s functions

subsection.content: The Secretary may give directions, not inconsistent with this Ordinance or the Electoral Affairs Commission Ordinance (Cap. 541), either generally or in any particular case, with respect to the performance by an electoral officer of any of the officer’s functions under this Ordinance or the Electoral Affairs Commission Ordinance (Cap. 541) with respect to the holding or conduct of an election.

An electoral officer shall, when performing a function under this Ordinance or the Electoral Affairs Commission Ordinance (Cap. 541), comply with any direction given by the Secretary under this section with respect to the performance of the function.

section.name: s57
section.heading: Death or incapacity of an electoral officer not to terminate authority
section.content: Death or incapacity of an electoral officer does not terminate any authority conferred by the officer for the purposes of this Ordinance.

section.name: s58
section.heading: Proceedings against persons on grounds of disqualification

subsection.content: The Secretary for Justice may bring proceedings in the Court against any person who is acting, or claims to be entitled to act, as a Rural Representative on the ground that the person is disqualified from acting as a Rural Representative.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: Immediately after proceedings are brought by the Secretary for Justice under this section against a person on the ground that the person is disqualified from acting as a Rural Representative—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for breach of the Rural Representative Oath taken under section 36B; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for failure to fulfil the legal requirements and conditions on upholding the Basic Law and bearing allegiance to the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China,

subsection.continued: the person’s functions as a Rural Representative are suspended until the decision of the Court in the proceedings becomes final. (Added 8 of 2022 s. 9)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2A), a decision of the Court becomes final—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if no motion for the purpose of an application for leave to appeal to the Court of Final Appeal under section 22(1)(g) of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 484) is filed by the end of the period specified under subsection (4B)—when that period expires; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if, before the end of that period, motion for the purpose of such an application is filed—

subparagraph.content: when the application is abandoned or otherwise ceases to have effect;
when the application is refused; or

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: when the appeal is abandoned or otherwise ceases to have effect; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: when the appeal is determined. (Added 8 of 2022 s. 9)

subsection.name: 2C
subsection.leadIn: If a person’s functions as a Rural Representative are suspended under subsection (2A), the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must not act as a Rural Representative;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must not do anything for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of this Ordinance or any other enactment conferring functions on a Rural Representative; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must not enjoy any corresponding entitlement. (Added 8 of 2022 s. 9)

subsection.name: 2D
subsection.content: The Court may, on the application of a person whose functions as a Rural Representative are suspended under subsection (2A), lift the suspension. (Added 8 of 2022 s. 9)

subsection.name: 2E
subsection.content: If a person acts, or claims to be entitled to act, as a Rural Representative while his or her functions as a Rural Representative are suspended under subsection (2A), the Secretary for Justice may apply to the Court for an interim injunction restraining the person from so acting or claiming. (Added 8 of 2022 s. 9)

subsection.leadIn: If, in proceedings brought under this section, it is proved that the defendant acted as a Rural Representative while disqualified from acting as a Rural Representative, the Court may— (Amended 5 of 2014 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make a declaration to that effect;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: grant an injunction restraining the defendant from so acting; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: order the defendant to pay to the Government such sum as the Court thinks appropriate, not exceeding $5,000 for each occasion on which the person so acted while disqualified.

subsection.leadIn: If, in proceedings brought under this section, it is proved that the defendant claimed to be entitled to act as a Rural Representative while disqualified from acting as a Rural Representative, the Court may— (Amended 5 of 2014 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make a declaration to that effect; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: grant an injunction restraining the defendant from so acting.

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.content: If, in proceedings brought under this section, it is proved that the defendant was disqualified from acting as a Rural Representative beginning on a date, the defendant ceased to be entitled to any corresponding entitlement beginning on that date. (Added 8 of 2022 s. 9)

subsection.name: 4B
subsection.content: Despite section 24 of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 484), notice of a motion for the purpose of an application for leave to appeal to the Court of Final Appeal under section 22(1)(g) of that Ordinance must be filed within 14 working days after the date on which the written judgment of the Court to be appealed from is handed down, and the applicant must give the opposite party 3 days’ notice of his or her intended application at any time during the period of 14 working days. (Added 8 of 2022 s. 9)

Proceedings against a person on the ground that the person has acted, or claimed to have been entitled to act, as a Rural Representative while disqualified from acting as a Rural Representative may be brought only in accordance with this section and by the Secretary for Justice.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section, a person is disqualified from acting as a Rural Representative if the person— (Amended 5 of 2014 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is not qualified to be, or is disqualified from being, a Rural Representative; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has ceased to hold the office of rural representative for a Rural Area.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (4B)—

def.name: WorkingDay
def.leadIn: working day (工作日) means any day other than—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a general holiday;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a black rainstorm warning day as defined by section 71(2) of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a gale warning day as defined by that section. (Added 8 of 2022 s. 9)

section.name: s59
section.heading: Period within which complaint or information shall be laid
section.content: Except as otherwise provided by this Ordinance, a complaint or information alleging the commission of an offence against this Ordinance shall be laid within 3 years after the date of the alleged commission.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Constitution of a Rural Committee to be construed in accordance with this Part

subsection.content: The constitution of a Rural Committee shall be construed in accordance with this Part.
This Part has effect notwithstanding any other enactment or rule of law.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: constitution (章程), in relation to a Rural Committee, includes the articles of association, or the rules, of the Rural Committee;
office holder (幹事), in relation to a Rural Committee, includes the Chairman and a Vice-Chairman of, and a member of the Executive Committee of, the Rural Committee.

section.name: s61
section.heading: Rural Representative as a member of Rural Committee

subsection.content: A Resident Representative for an Existing Village is, by virtue of being such a Resident Representative, a member of the Rural Committee specified in column 5 of Schedule 1 opposite the name of the Village specified in column 1 of that Schedule.

An Indigenous Inhabitant Representative for an Indigenous Village is, by virtue of being such an Indigenous Inhabitant Representative, a member of the Rural Committee specified in column 4 of Schedule 2 opposite the name of the Village specified in column 1 of that Schedule.

An Indigenous Inhabitant Representative for a Composite Indigenous Village is, by virtue of being such an Indigenous Inhabitant Representative, a member of the Rural Committee specified in column 5 of Schedule 3 opposite the name of the Village specified in column 1 of that Schedule.

A Kaifong Representative for a Market Town is, by virtue of being such a Kaifong Representative, a member of the Rural Committee specified in column 5 of Schedule 3A opposite the name of the Market Town specified in column 1 of that Schedule. (Added 5 of 2014 s. 12)

section.name: s62
section.heading: Members and office holders of a Rural Committee

subsection.content: The term of office of each member and office holder of a Rural Committee that commenced on 1 April 1999 is extended to 4 years and 6 months.

On the expiry of the term of office mentioned in subsection (1), there is, in relation to each member and office holder of the Rural Committee, a term of office of 3 years and 6 months that commences on 1 October 2003.

The electoral arrangements, and the conduct, of an election to elect an office holder of a Rural Committee shall be consistent with Article 21(a) and (b) of the Hong Kong Bill of Rights set out in Part II of the Hong Kong Bill of Rights Ordinance (Cap. 383).

section.name: s64
section.heading: Elector for an Indigenous Village or a Composite Indigenous Village not to have status of indigenous inhabitant for the Village
section.leadIn: For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the fact that a person is registered as an elector for an Indigenous Village or a Composite Indigenous Village does not, for all purposes, mean that the person is an indigenous inhabitant (whether within the meaning of this Ordinance or otherwise) of the Village; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the provisional, and final, register for the Village shall be construed accordingly in any proceedings.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Secretary may make regulations

subsection.content: The Secretary may make regulations for the better carrying out of the purposes of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In particular, a regulation under this section may provide for all or any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the functions of a Revising Officer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: appeals to a Revising Officer.

subsection.content: A provision of a regulation under this section may make it an offence, punishable by a fine not exceeding level 2, for a person to contravene a provision of the regulation.

subsection.leadIn: A regulation under this section may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make different provisions for different circumstances and provide for a particular case or class of cases;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be made so as to apply only in specified circumstances; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: prescribe fees for the purposes of the regulation.

section.name: s66
section.heading: Chief Justice may make rules
section.leadIn: The Chief Justice may make rules to provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the preparation, lodgement, service, trial and withdrawal of election petitions;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: costs in respect of election petitions and the giving of security for such costs;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the practice and procedure concerning the trial of election petitions; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other matters for the better carrying out of the objects and purposes of Part 5.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Secretary may amend Schedule 1, 2, 3 or 3A

subsection.content: The Secretary may, by order published in the Gazette, amend Schedule 1, 2, 3 or 3A. (Amended 5 of 2014 s. 13)
An order under this section may contain such incidental, consequential, supplemental, transitional or saving provisions as may be necessary or expedient in consequence of the order.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Transitional provisions relating to Rural Representative Election Legislation (Amendment) Ordinance 2014
section.content: Schedule 6 sets out transitional provisions relating to the Rural Representative Election Legislation (Amendment) Ordinance 2014 (5 of 2014).

schedule.name: sch6
schedule.heading: Transitional Provisions Relating to Rural Representative Election Legislation (Amendment) Ordinance 2014

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation

def.name: MarketTown
def.leadIn: Market Town (墟鎮) means—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the Market Town known as “Peng Chau” which is included in Schedule 3A added by section 16 of the amending Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: The first election for a Market Town
section.content: The first election to elect a person as a Kaifong Representative for a Market Town is to be held in 2015.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Registration of electors for Market Towns
section.content: Section 15(1)(a) does not apply in relation to the registration of a person as an elector for a Market Town in the first provisional register, or the first final register, to be compiled and published for that Market Town after the date on which the amending Ordinance is published in the Gazette*.

editorialNote.content: * Date of publication in the Gazette : 4 April 2014.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Compilation of first Market Towns provisional register
section.content: Section 17(3), (4)(a) and (b), (5) and (6) does not apply in relation to the compilation of the first provisional register for Market Towns after the date on which the amending Ordinance is published in the Gazette*.

editorialNote.content: * Date of publication in the Gazette : 4 April 2014.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: I will duly and faithfully fulfil the functions of a Rural Representative according to the best of my ability;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: I will uphold the Basic Law;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: I will bear allegiance to the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to the best of my knowledge and belief I am not disqualified from holding office as a Rural Representative by virtue of section 9 of the Rural Representative Election Ordinance (Cap. 576).
(Signature) …………………….
This oath was **affirmed/sworn and signed before me, a **Commissioner for Oaths/Justice of the Peace/Solicitor with a practising certificate.
